The characters riding on the inside of the coach who are observed by the narrator during the heatwave in The Hard Summer. They consist of the fat gentleman, an overheated young boy, his mother, and a pale girl.
The characters riding on the outside of the coach who are observed by the narrator during the heatwave in The Hard Summer.
The group of young local boys whose cricket match the narrator stops to watch in The Hard Summer. The players include Jem Eusden, Joe Kirby, and the little hussar.
Characters mentioned in the Our Village story, The First Primrose. They are the fourteen children of the amiable Rachel and Joseph White.

org.orgName: boys at the Our Village illumination
org.note: A group of young boys, mentioned in Our Village who enthusiastically participate in the illumination organized by the retired publican in celebration of Queen Caroline's acquittal.
The three journeymen who work for the village shoemaker. They are mentioned in Our Village.
Characters from the Arabian Nights tale of The Porter and the Three Ladies.
The local parish workhouse mentioned in several Our Village sketches, including Our Village, Violeting, and The First Primrose.
Group of girls in red cloaks observed by the narrator on her walk in Frost.
Group of small landowners in and around Three Mile Cross who allow foot traffic on their lands. They are mentioned in The Cowslip Ball.
The large array of relations enumerated by the narrator who have pre-deceased the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady, and whose lives she can discuss in great detail.
The village church in Three Mile Cross as represented in Our Village.

person.note: In Greek mythology, Achilles was the son of the nereid Thetis and King Peleus of Phthia in Thessaly. While he was an infant, a prophesy foretold that he would either gain glory and die young, or die old without fame, so he chose the former. His mother sought to protect him from harm by dipping him in the River Styx, leaving only his ankles unprotected. He is essentially the hero of the Trojan War and The Iliad, though he died in that war after avenging his friend, Patroclus.
One of the three Charites in ancient Greek religion. A daughter of Zeus, a Goddess of Joy or Mirth, and the incarnation of grace and beauty.

Goliath is the Philistine giant that the future King David of Israel slays with a sling. The term David and Goliath has come to represent an underdog situation in which the underdog is victorious. Goliath is also representative of Christ's defeat of Satan in the New Testament as the Philistines represent paganism, and Kind David is one of the anscestors of Christ in Christianity. The story of David and Goliath is found in 1 Samuel 17. The story is important Biblically as it is David's defeat of Goliath that leads King Saul to appoint David as head of the Israelite army, leading to David's ascension to the Israelite throne.
The mother of Moses, Aaron, and Miriam.
King of the gods in ancient Roman and Greek religions, he controls the sky and the thunder. In Rome, he was known as Jove and Jupiter, while in Greece, he was called Zeus.
In Greek mythology, Medusa is a Gorgon with snakes for hair. A glimpse of her face will turn the onlooker to stone.

The prophet of Judaic and Christian traditions who was chosen by God to lead the enslaved Israelites out of Egypt, and who delivered the Ten Commandments to the people, building a covenant between them and God. After forty years wandering in the desert, Moses led them to the promised land of Canaan, but was himself not allowed to enter.
Character featured in the Our Village story, The First Primrose. She is the wife of a gardener who sometimes worked for the narrator's family , and who lives separately from her.
Character introduced in the Our Village story, the First Primrose. He is a gardener who worked for the narrator's family,the husband of Betty Adams, but he lives in a different town.

Character from A Country Cricket Match. She is the love-interest of James Brown whose plea for him to come to play for her town's team prevents him from participating in the Shinfield match against the team from B.. She is from the town of M..
Character who serves as the main servant to Mr. Sidney's in An Old Bachelor, and acts on behalf of the household owner. Forename not given.
Character appearing in A Country Cricket Match. He is the sixth player chosen for the Shinfield cricket team, and is distinguished for his good humor.
Character who appears in the sketch Tom Cordery. We learn that Tom thoroughly defeated him in a fight.
Character of the housekeeper mentioned in Aunt Martha.
The beloved patriarch of the household in which Aunt Martha lives in Aunt Martha. He may be the fictionalized portrait of James Webb.
The peddler and thief who appears in Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale.
Character introduced in the Our Village story, The First Primrose. She is the wife of Mr. Barnard, a wealthy farmer. Forename not given.
Character mentioned in the Our Village story, The First Primrose. He is the adopted nephew of of farmer Barnard and his wife, who have no children of their own.
Character introduced in the Our Village story, The First Primsrose. He is a wealthy farmer who lives near the narrator. Forename not given.

In the Our Village sketch, Bramley Maying, the unidentified character who accompanies the narrator to the Maying. From the character's description in the text as someone widely known for ten miles, the person is likely the narrator's father, based on George Mitford.
In the Our Village sketch, Bramley Maying, he is the character who provides the narrator and her companion with the key to the church when they arrive in Bramley. Name not given.
In the Our Village sketch, Bramley Maying, he is the character who guides the narrator and her companion on a tour of the Bramley church. Name not given.
One of the characters whom the narrator encounters in the Our Village sketch, Bramley Maying. Name not given.
In the Our Village sketch, Bramley Maying, this character attends the Maying rather than attending to visitors of the church. Name not given.

Character mentioned in A Country Cricket Match as the farmer for whom Joel Brent works. He succumbs to social pressure and allows Joel to join the Shinfield cricket team and play in the match against the team from B. rather than bringing in the hay harvest. Name not given.
A character in The Faerie Queene by Edmund Spenser.
This character appears in the sketch Nutting. He farms an apple and pear orchard together with his large family. Forename not given.
This character appears in Nutting, in which she is seen at the fruit harvest with her family. Forename not given.

This character appears in Nutting at the fruit harvest with his family, and later gathers nuts with the narrator. He is said to be about six- or seven-years old, and the narrator imagines him betrothed to Lizzy.
This young girl appears in Nutting, where she is seen happily gathering the apples that her older brother flings down from a tree. Forename not given.
This character appears in Nutting, in which he is shown climbing to the top of a pear-tree and shaking down the fruit during the harvest. Forename not given.
This character appears in Nutting, where he is seen pelting apples down from a tree at his younger sister during the harvest. Forename not given.
This character, an infant, is observed in Nutting eating some of the harvested fruit. Forename not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the married brother of James Brown, with whom the latter has come to reside after six years as a journeyman blacksmith. Forename not given.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. She is the wife of James Brown's brother, and sister-in-law to James Brown. She is the one who delivers the letter from Mary Allen to James, which leads him to abandon the match. Forename not given.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. After traveling as a journeyman blacksmith for six years, he has returned to Shinfield, where he is commended as the best cricket player on the Shinfield cricket team. His secret relationship with Mary Allen from a neighboring town leads him to abscond from playing the match against the team from B.. Notes from Francis Needham's archives suggest that a blacksmith named Benjamin Brown may have served as the model for this character.

Suitor and later husband of Lucy. The real life counterpart of this character is Charles Hill, who married the real life Lucy Sweetser. He appears in several Our Village sketches, notably Lucy and Bramley Maying.
A hunting dog mentioned in Nutting.
Character in Emma who flirts with the title character.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is one of the Shinfield cricketers, and is considered a good batter. He is also mentioned in The Hard Summer.
The wife of Tom Cordery in the story of the same name in Our Village. Forename not given.
Title character of the Our Village sketch. Despite being a tricky and unreliable hunting guide for local gentlemen, as well as a well-known poacher, he is liked and admired in the area.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. His alliance with the high church curate enables the renewal of cricket in Shinfield. Name not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. His alliance with the evangelical farmer enables the renewal of cricket in Shinfield. Name not given.
Character, a publican, who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He, along with the Rose Inn Landlord, donates ribbons for the cricket games. Name not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. She is a child thief who steals the handkerchief of Samuel Long after the match.
The umpire who appears in A Country Cricket Match. Name not given.
The twelve-year old daughter of Sir W.S. in the Our Village sketch, Cousin Mary. Forename not given.
The seven-year old son of Sir W.S. in the Our Village sketch, Cousin Mary. Forename not given.
Character appearing in the Our Village sketch, Cousin Mary, whom the title character helps climb the hill. Name not given.
She is the mostly deaf grandmother of Sally Wheeler who lives with her granddaughter. Forename not given.
Roman goddess of wild animals and the hunt.
Character from the Our Village sketch Ellen. She is the nurse of Charlotte Page and Ellen Page. No formal name given.
One of the country boys who plays a skillful game of cricket in The Hard Summer. He is said to be about 13-years old, and is a rival of Joe Kirby.

This character appears in The Visit. She is the infant daughter of the friend from F. Hill whom the narrator visits, and is the fictional counterpart of Frances Dickinson. Surname not given in the text.
Character who appears in The Visit accompanying his daughters as they sing and play during a call on the great house. Name not given in the text.
This character, who is mentioned in The Visit, is based on Charles Dickinson. Name not given in the text.

person.persName: sister of the F. Hill friend
person.note: In The Visit, this character is referred to as the sister of the F. Hill friend as she sings. Name not given.
This character, who appears in The Visit, hosts the narrator at her home in F. Hill. She is based on Mitford's friend, Catherine Dickinson. Name not given in the text.
A character who appears in The Visit.
Character in Emma who has little money or prospects.
Character who appears in the Our Village sketch Ellen. He is the father of Miss Falkner and William Falkner.
Character from the Our Village sketch Ellen. She is the sister of Colonel Falkner and the sister-in-law of Ellen Page. No forename given.
Character from the Our Village sketch Ellen. He is the brother of Miss Falkner and becomes the husband of Ellen Page.
Character from Shakespeare's Henry IV part 1 who serves as page to Falstaff. His later life unfolds in Henry V.
A character in The Faerie Queene by Edmund Spenser.

Welsh rebel hero of legend and history, widely popularized in Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part 1. Born to a noble Welsh family, he was trained at the Inns of Court in London. The rebellion he led against the English began as a land dispute... In the play, he is depicted as a wild man, who claims to be able to call up spirits, and it is in this sense that Mitford generally refers to him. Source: ODNB.

Member of Parliament mentioned in A Great Farmhouse, whose estates are managed by the farmer. Given the timing of the narrator's recollections, and the fact that this sketch has origins in an 1816 letter, it is possible that the Member of Parliament referred to is Charles Shaw-Lefevre, who at that time was representing Reading.

The farmer of this sketch is never named. However, letter evidence suggests that Mitford is recalling her friend Mr. Newell of Whitby Hill farm, who died in October 1816. After his death, Mitford was given one his greyhounds, Nell. (See Letter to Mary Webb, October 28, 1816.)
Son of the farming couple whom Mitford recollects with fondness in A Great Farmhouse.

This character is not named in the sketch. However, letter evidence suggests that Mitford is recalling her friends, the Newells of Whitby Park. Mr. Newell died in October 1816, and the Mitfords remained in contact with his widow for some years afterwards, according to Mitford's Journal.

Character who appears in several Our Village sketches, but most prominently in A Country Cricket Match, where he is the captain of the cricket team who also organizes the team's players. He is noted as a rival of Joel Brent in A Village Beau, and is also mentioned in The Hard Summer.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. Grover, known as a man of good judgment, acts as a spy on the B. parish cricket team to report on the team's skills. He also brings the news that Joel Brent cannot participate in the match.
By the end of Our Village, 1st series, she is the new servant for the Our Village narrator's family, replacing Lucy. She is the fictional counterpart of Harriet Keep. Surename not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the seventh man chosen for the cricket team.

Character mentioned in A Country Cricket Match. He is the father-in-law of Joseph Hearne, and the man with whom the latter lodges, making him eligible to play on the Shinfield cricket team. Name not given.

Character in A Country Cricket Match. He works at the A. Mills in a neighboring parish, but lodges in Shinfield parish at the home of his father-in-law. Despite being an excellent cricket player, his hesitancy about playing on the Shinfield cricket team in their match against the B. parish team leads him to be rejected for play by William Grey.

"goddess of youth; daughter of Zeus and Hera and wife of Hercules. She appears only occasionally in legend as a cupbearer and attendant of the gods. The Romans identified her as Juventas." "Hebe." The Columbia Electronic Encyclopedia. 2013. Columbia University Press 12 Apr. 2017 http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Hebe

The Greek mythological queen whose abduction sparked the Trojan War. She is depicted in many literary works such as The Iliad and The Odyssey. She is also the titular character in Euripides' play Helen .

In Shakespeare's history play Henry IV Part 1, he is a main character, a rebel against the king who is killed by Prince Hal. He, as well as the events depicted in the play, is based on the real-life Sir Henry Percy and the rebellion he led against King Henry IV.
Character mentioned in The Visit.
A pleasant young cricket player who appears in The Hard Summer, and a friend of the narrator. It is likely that this character was based on a real-life Joseph Kirby.
Character mentioned in The Visit.

person.persName: Sarah Kirby from Our Village Kirby not given Sarah Mrs.
person.note: Mother of Ben Kirby and Joe Kirby as she appears in several Our Village sketches.

person.persName: Harry L. L. Henry Harry Major
person.note: The titular protagonist of The Talking Gentleman. In this portrait, Harry is described as an energetic jovial, witty man who, despite being an incessant talker, is a beloved well-known local personality. His last name is not given in full.
The wife of Harry L. in the sketch The Talking Gentleman. She is unnamed in the sketch, and all readers learn about her is that she has property in Devonshire. Forename not given.

The lady is mentioned in the Our Village story, Bramley Maying, and is likely a reference to Harriot Brocas, wife of Bernard Brocas, who was known to spend little time at their newly renovated estate, Beaurepaire House, after her husband's death, prefering to stay at Wokefield Park.
One of Lucy's more noteworthy lovers who appears in the Our Village story, Lucy. He was not a part of the group of three lovers. A talented tailor, he left Lucy after she consented to marry him.
Character mentioned in A Country Cricket Match. She is the mother of Samuel Long, and the maker of the handkerchief that is stolen. Forename not given.

A character who appears in several Our Village sketches. He is one of the Shinfield cricket team in A Country Cricket Match. He is a middle-aged man, a day-laborer, who has recently moved back to Shinfield from S. parish. S. parish. He is known as a good bowler. He also appears in The Visit.

person.persName:
Lucy Lucy
Title character of the Our Village story. Lucy is a beloved servant in the narrator's household who leaves to get married. She appears or is mentioned in several stories, notably Hannah and A Visit to Lucy. She is based on Lucy Sweetser Hill, whose marriage to Charles Hill in 1820 led to her move to Silchester to teach school. Her paternal last name is not given.

person.note: One of Lucy's three one-eyed lovers, the most prominent of the group, who courted her for ten years.

Character in Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose. As someone who was adopted as a young child, her parentage is obscure throughout much of the novel, and as a result, the two men who love her and violently compete for her are reluctant to marry her. She is represented as an excellent singer and harp player.

Character who appears in the Our Village story, Bramley Maying. He is the butcher of the village of M. who gives the narrator and her companion complicated directions to the Maying after they have lost their way. Name not given.
Character who appears in Bramley Maying. He gives the narrator and her companion directions to the Maying, and later accompanies them on part of their journey. Name not given.
In the Robin Hood legends, Maid Marian is the hero's paramour.

Title character of Aunt Martha, who is described as a beloved unmarried member of a a gentleman and his daughters' household. It has been speculated that she is a fictionalized portrait of Mary Webb. Surname not given.
The deceased father of Cousin Mary in the sketch Cousin Mary. Name not given.
Mother of the title character in the Our Village sketch, Cousin Mary, who is admired for giving her daughter a natural education with no accomplishments. Forename not given.
Sister of the title character of the Our Village sketch, Cousin Mary, with whom Mary lives before becoming a governess, and who is a notorious matchmaker. Name not given.
Title character from the Our Village sketch Cousin Mary. She is raised without accomplishments and is beloved by all. Surname not given in full.
In Shakespeare's play, The Merry Wives of Windsor, Slender is a foolish character whom Anne Page tricks as part of the larger trick on Falstaff.
One of the young women vying for Joel Brent's hand in marriage. She speaks badly of anyone she considers a rival.
Character mentioned in A Village Beau. He is the brother of Sophia Matthews and works as a collar-maker. Forename not given.
Character mentioned in A Village Beau. He is the late father of Sophia Matthews, who worked as a collar-maker. Forename not given.

The title character of the Mrs. Mosse. In the sketch, Mossy is recalled as an elderly servant, based on the real Elizabeth Cropp, who worked in the household of Dr. Richard Russell before Mary Russell was born.
Half-nephew and natural heir of Mrs. Mosse, the title character of the Our Village sketch. He and his wife are said to live in Prince's Street, Barbican. Forename not given.
Half-niece by marriage of Mrs. Mosse, the title character of the Our Village sketch. She and her husband are said to live in Prince's Street, Barbican. Forename not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. She is among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. He is among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse, who is considered the area rake and shows interest in Fanny.
A person whom the title character of Mrs. Mosse remembers. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. He offends Mitford's maternal grandfather by saluting his wife. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse. He is among the many visitors to Mitford's maternal grandmother's home. Name not given.
Charactor mentioned in Mrs. Mosse, whose daughter imprudently marries the son of Dr. Russell's first wife. Name not given.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse, who imprudently marries the son of Dr. Russell's first wife. Name not given.

The first wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather. She is recalled in the Our Village sketch, Mrs. Mosse as a wealthy widow with a son, considerably older than her husband, and someone who thought herself better than other people. Forename not given.
The first husband of Mitford's maternal grandfather's first wife. He is mentioned in the Our Village sketch, Mrs. Mosse. Forename not given.
The son of the first wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather, who makes a bad marital match that shames his mother. He is recalled in the Our Village sketch, Mrs. Mosse. Name not given.

person.persName: The second wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather. She is recalled in Mrs. Mosse, and is remembered chiefly for participating in an innoculation party. Forename not given.

person.note: Farmer friend of the Mitfords, likely the basis of the farmer recollected in A Great Farmhouse.
Friend of the Mitfords who is, letter evidence suggests, likely the basis for the farmer's wife featured in A Great Farmhouse. Her forename is unidentified.

In Shakespeare's The Tempest, he is King of the Fairies, married to Titania. In order to win a dispute with his wife over the fate of a child, Oberon causes his wife to fall in love with a human whose head has been turned into a donkey's.
A significant opponent of Mr. Sidney at whist in An Old Bachelor. Name not given.
Character of the gardener to Mr. Sidney, who appears in An Old Bachelor. Name not given.

person.persName: girl at party in An Old Bachelor
person.note: A young girl mentioned in An Old Bachelor who attends Mr. Sidney's Christmas parties along with the narrator when she was a child. Name not given.
Character of the long-lived occupant of the unnamed rectorythat Mr. Sidney is waiting to occupy in An Old Bachelor. Name not given.

person.persName: young visitor in An Old Bachelor
person.note: Character who is visiting the Our Village narrator's family when the story of Mr. Sidney is told in An Old Bachelor. Name not given.

Obscure author of tracts on the poor laws and on the French Revolution who is discussed by the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady as someone on whose life she can give minute details. Mentioned with irritation by the narrator.
Appears in the Our Village sketch Ellen. The husband of Charlotte Page.

Character from the Our Village sketch Ellen. Charlotte is the twin sister of Ellen, daughter of the rector of N.. She is the livelier of the two sisters, and becomes engaged to a soon-to-be ordained man.

Title character from the Our Village sketch Ellen. She is the daughter of a rector, twin sister of Charlotte Page. She is the less lively and less preferred of the two sisters, and becomes engaged to Colonel Falkner.
Character mentioned in the Our Village sketch Ellen. She is the deceased mother of Charlotte Page and Ellen Page.
Character in Henry Fielding's novel, Joseph Andrews. He believes the best of everyone, and is often the victim of deceit.
Character mentioned in several Our Village sketches as the man who married Phoebe. He is unnamed, and said to be a patten-maker.

persName.roleName: King of England and of France and Lord of Ireland

person.note: Prince Hal is typically known as the youthful character of King Henry V before he became king, as made famous in Shakespeare's plays Henry IV Part 1 and Henry IV Part 2. In these plays, he carouses with Falstaff and other colorful, low-born characters, rendering his interest in ruling the kingdom a matter of critical debate. In Shakespeare's Henry IV Part 1, it is Hal who kills Hotspur at the Battle of Shrewsbury.

"In Roman mythology, Psyche represented the human spirit and was portrayed as a beautiful girl with butterfly wings. Psyche was a beautiful mortal desired by Cupid, to the dismay of Cupid's mother Venus. Venus demanded that her son order Psyche to fall in love with the ugliest man in the world. Cupid refused and loved Psyche himself, visiting her only by night and commanding that she not look at him. Eventually, Psyche broke Cupid's rule and lit a lamp to look upon his face. For this disloyalty, Cupid abandoned her and Psyche wandered through the world in search of her lover. Eventually she was reunited with Cupid and made immortal by Jupiter." http://www.encyclopedia.com/literature-and-arts/classical-literature-mythology-and-folklore/folklore-and-mythology/psyche
A spaniel belonging to Joel Brent, mentioned in A Village Beau.

One of the country boys whom the narrator of Our Village encounters or mentions in a number of sketches, notably Frost and Thaw and A Country Cricket Match. In his Mitford papers, Francis Needham identifies two local boys by this name on whom this character was likely based.
Character of the rector from the Our Village sketch Ellen. He is the widowed father of Charlotte and Ellen Page, who has a good living in N. as well as an estate in Ireland. Forename not given.

Outlaw hero of medieval legend who, together with his merry men, figures in ballads, broadsides, plays, games, proverbs, film, and television from the fourteenth century till our own time, but whose historal existence remains a matter of debate. He is a complex figure in the long tradition that he occupies, but is best known as a benevolent outlaw, who battles the Sheriff of Nottingham for the good of the poor. In Mitford's time, the most influential scholars on Robin Hood were Thomas Percy and Joseph Ritson. Their antiquarian research helped shape a national English hero, and influenced Walter Scott's depiction of the character in Ivanhoe, as well as the representations found in John Keats' short poem, and Thomas Love Peacock's novel, Maid Marian.
Character mentioned in Mrs. Mosse, likely referring to the real-life sister of Mary Russell. In the sketch, she gains the attentions of the neighborhood rake, Sir Thomas S.. Surname not given.
The third wife of Mitford's maternal grandfather, and Mitford's maternal grandmother, Mary Dicker Russell. She is recalled fondly in the Mrs. Mosse.
Mary Russell Mitford's maternal grandfather, Richard Russell, as he is described but not named in the Our Village sketch, Mrs. Mosse.
The dog who belonged to Mitford's maternal grandfather, and that is described vividly by the title character in Mrs. Mosse.
The village schoolmistress mentioned in Our Village. She is said frequently to let herself be dominated by Lizzy.
Character of the Three Mile Cross schoolmaster who is mentioned in The Hard Summer. Name not given.
Character who appears in the sketch Tom Cordery. We learn that one of Tom's legendary feats was to level him to the ground with a dead hare.

Whig Member of Parliament who represented the borough of Reading for several years, fighting a number of contested elections. He was acquainted with the Mitford family, and they socialized in the early part of the nineteenth century. Mitford's nickname for him was Gog. He may be the local Member of Parliament mentioned in A Great Farmhouse, whose estates are managed by the farmer .
The main character of An Old Bachelor. Forename not given.

Character who appears in Bramley Maying who reveals that the narrator and her companion have reached Silchester. She gives the narrator and her companion directions to the Maying as they make their way to the festival. Name not given.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the third person chosen to join the Shinfield cricket team, known as a fast thrower. He is the brother of John Simmons.
Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is a member of the Shinfield cricket team, known for his good fielding skills, and he is the brother of George Simmons.
Character of a wealthy baronet from Waleswho appears in the Our Village sketch, Cousin Mary. He hires Mary as a governess for his children, but later marries her. Full name not given.
Wealthy young baronet widow who appears in the Our Village sketch, Cousin Mary.

Princess character made famous by Charles Perrault in his Stories or Tales of Times Past, who falls asleep for one hundred years after a spindle prick, and awakens just at the moment that a prince approaches her. Perrault's version of the tale follows the princess and prince after their marriage, when the prince's ogre-mother attempts to kill the princess and her children.
Character in Henry Fielding's novel, Tom Jones. He is the good-natured guardian of the novel's title character.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the son of the village mason, although his occupation is not given. He is rejected from the Shinfield cricket team for being too tall and lacking in strength, but is later called on to play after James Brown abandons the team.
A soldier who appears in The Talking Gentleman. He becomes concerned about Harry L. when he witnesses him apparently talking to himself. Name not given.
Cousin of the title character of the sketch, . She is mentioned in passing. Surname not given.
A person who is the subject of the the talking lady's endless talk. Forename not given.
A person who is the subject of the the talking lady's endless chatter. Name not given.
A person who is the subject of the the talking lady's endless talk.
One of the passengers on the mail coach with whom the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady shares her journey west.
One of the passengers on the mail coach with whom the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady shares her journey west.
One of the passengers on the mail coach with whom the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady shares her journey west. Name not given.

The last nephew of the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady whose death leads her to move in with the widow, and subsequently, to take the trip that brings her to visit the the narrator's family. Name not given.
A woman who is mentioned as having unsuccessfully set up house with the title character of The Talking Lady. Name not given.

Unnamed title character of the Our Village sketch, The Talking Lady. She is an old acquaintance of the narrator's father, possibly based on someone Mitford knew. In The Talking Gentleman, she is mentioned to have died.
This horse appears in The Visit. He belongs to the Our Village narrator's Farley Hill friend, and comically refuses to obey the latter's directions.

In Shakespeare's The Tempest, she is Queen of the Fairies. As a result of a marital dispute over the fate of a child, she is tricked by her husband, Oberon, to fall in love with a human whose head has been transformed into that of a donkey.
Character mentioned in the sketch Tom Cordery. Surname not given.
Character who appears in the sketch Tom Cordery. He acts as something of an ally and friend to Tom by turning a blind eye to his poaching. Name not given.

Character mentioned in the sketch Tom Cordery. It is difficult to discern anything about this character other than that he is a member of the nobility. In the story, he appears as someone about whom Tom tells hunting tales to distract and tempt his clients into unattractive hunting grounds.Name not given.

person.persName: Overseer of estate forename not given surname not given
person.note: Character who appears in Tom Cordery. He is the overseer of the estate on which the title character's cottage sits. It is he who declines to repair the Corderys' cottage after a snowfall destroys the roof.
A character in The Faerie Queene by Edmund Spenser.
A young carpenter who competes with Joel Brent_for the affections of Harriet in A Village Beau. Name not given.
In the Our Village sketch, Violeting, this character is mentioned as a landlord whose carelessness has affected his tenants and the farmhouse they live in. Name not given.
An old man whom the narrator sees digging in workhouse garden in the sketch, Violeting. Name not given.
In the Our Village sketch, Violeting, this character is mentioned as a tenant who lives in an old farmhouse that is crumbling due to the careless landlord. Name not given.
Mr. Sidney's pet terrier in An Old Bachelor.
The character of the coachman whom the narrator observes in The Hard Summer. He is not identified by name. Name not given.
An overheated character mentioned in The Hard Summer whom the narrator sees in the coach. Name not given.
A character who assists the narrator water her flowers during a drought in The Hard Summer. Name and gender not given, but it is suggested they work in the stable.
An overheated character mentioned in The Hard Summer whom the narrator sees in the coach. Name not given.
An overheated character mentioned in The Hard Summer whom the narrator sees in the coach. Name not given.
Character of an 8-year old cricket player who appears in The Hard Summer. The narrator does not know his name, and so she denotes him by his dress, which resembles that of a hussar.

persName.note: An overheated character mentioned in The Hard Summer whom the narrator sees in the coach. Name not given.

person.note: Character mentioned in The Hard Summer as a prosperous, industrious local farmer. He is married to Mrs. Welles. Forename not given.
Character mentioned in The Hard Summer. She is the wife of Master Welles, and together, they run a prosperous farm in the area. Her forename is not given. Forename not given.
Sally Wheeler is one of the women vying for the affections of Joel Brent in the Our Village sketch, A Village Beau.

Character mentioned in the Our Village story, The First Primrose. The son of a farmer, he is the cheery husband of Rachel White. They are noted to be a cheerful, industrious, poor family of fourteen children.

Character introduced in the Our Village story, The First Primrose, described as a jovial woman, married to Joseph White, daughter of Mr. Hilton, a former gamekeeper. She and her husband have fourteen children.
Character mentioned in the Our Village sketch, The First Primrose. He is the father Rachel Hilton White. Forename not given.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the eleventh person on the Shinfield cricket team, and the fifteen-year old brother of Robert Willis. Francis Needham's archival research found references to three blacksmiths from a Willis family, including David.

Character who appears in A Country Cricket Match. He is the tenth member of the Shinfield cricket team. He is the brother of David Willis. Francis Needham's archival research found three local blacksmiths from a Willis family, including a John, Thomas, and David, but none named Robert.
A ghostly white lady, described in the Our Village story, The First Primrose, who is said to haunt a small pool near the narrator's old house.
The landlord of the narrator and her family in Our Village. He may be based on Richard Body. Name not given.
In the Our Village sketch, Violeting, the narrator facetiously imagines how a long-ago lord was prevented from making an enclosure in Shinfield parish. Name not given.
A character mentioned in The Visit. He is said to dislike Ben Kirby. Name not given.
This character is mentioned in The Visit when the narrator admires his house. Name not given.
This character is mentioned in The Visit. He is said to have pulled down his picturesque house and mill and put up modern buildings. Name not given.

org.note: In Greek mythology, the Myrmidons were people of Phthia who were destroyed by a plague and later re-created from ants. In The Iliad, they are the soldiers who are loyal to Achilles

place.note: The capital city of Antwerp Province in the Flemish Region, known colloquially as Flanders, in Belgium. Before the Reformation, Antwerp rose to become a powerful trading city under the rule of the Spanish. With the Union of Utrecht in 1579, the city became part of the United Provinces of the Netherlands, and the port was subsequently closed by treaty agreement, leading to the decline in the city's trading status. During Mitford's lifetime, Antwerp was controlled by Napoleonic France, and after the Battle of Waterloo, it became part of the Kingdom of the United Netherlands until 1832, when it was joined to Belgium following a siege by French forces.
Area within the London City Corporation.

Beaurepaire House was the seat and estate of the Brocas family, located in Bramley, and including substantial lands. The house was demolished and replaced with a gothic-style manor around 1738, and was home to Bernard Brocas until his death, though it remained in the family and sometimes visited Harriot Brocas. The estate remained in the family until it was sold in 1870.
A fashionable shopping street in London.
Village in Hampshire, located ten miles south of Reading, near Silchester.
English country house that has been the seat of the Earls of Essex since Elizabethan times. Its name is featured in stories and poems about Henry Cecil and his second wife, Sarah Hoggins.

An area that was set aside for the poor at the enclosure of Mortimer Common in 1802. The spot features prominently in Tom Cordery as a place where the protagonist leads his clients on unsuccessful hunting trips.
City in the West Midlands in England.
The county of Devonshire, now known as Devon, in the south west of England.
A county in South West England on the English Channel coast. While known as Dorset today, it was archaically known as Dorsetshire.

A piece of ground near Mortimer Common mentioned in Tom Cordery as a spot where two murderers were hanged. Mitford recalls going to this place in a letter of January 13, 1842 to Elizabeth Barrett Browning.
A channel that runs through Reading off the Kennet River.
Tributary of the Thames that flows 28 miles northward from Basingstoke through Swallowfield, Shinfield to Wargrave. The river has for centuries been a location for milling operations.
Abbreviation used for the area in which the great farmhouse is located, from the sketch of the Our Village sketch of the same name.
The farmhouse whose inhabitants Mitford recalls in A Great Farmhouse.
Village in Berkshire located seven miles south-west of Reading.
Forest in north Hampshire, near Silchester.
Town described in the Our Village story, Lucy as a beautiful, Roman-walled town, and mentioned as the eventual residence of Lucy after her marriage. Probably Silchester.
The 481-mile long river that flows from northeastern France through Paris, Le Havre/Honfleur, and into the English Channel.

This village in East Hampshire is on the northern most boundary of what is currently South Downs national park. Gilbert White made his natural observations here when writing A Naturalist's Calendar and The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne.
Artificial lake, created in 1730 that occupies 40 acres in .

Shinfield parish is located in the county of Berkshire and contains Three Mile Cross, Spencer's Wood, Grazeley, and the village of Shinfield. Many of Mitford's sketches are set in and around the parish.
Village in Hampshire, nine miles from Reading, known for its Roman ruins. It is featured in several stories in Our Village, sometimes by name, sometimes through the abbreviation S.
Part of the Roman ruins in the town of Silchester.

place.placeName: Spice Islands Maluku Islands the Moluccas
place.note: An archipelago in the east of Indonesia that, from the seventeenth to the nineteenth centuries, was a center for the culture of cloves, mace, and nutmeg for colonizing European powers such as the Netherlands and Portugal. During Mitford's time, the region was under the control of the British.

Church located in Bramley, Hampshire that dates from the tweflth century, undergoing many renovations since that time. The church is notable for its beautiful stained glass and its elaborate marble tomb sculpture of Bernard Brocas. It is featured in the Our Village story, Bramley Maying, when the narrator and her companion take a tour.
A district in the City of Westminster, London. The area was being developed in Mitford's time as a suburban residential location.

Estate acquired through marriage by the second earl of Clarendon. The estate sits where the rivers Loddon and Blackwater join. The estate had been the property of the Backhouse family, who occupied an old Tudor mansion that was renovated and modernized. Swallowfield Park was subsequently sold by Hyde's son, the third earl, to Thomas 'Diamond' Pitt, great-grandfather of William Pitt the younger. He had made his fortune in India, famously by the purchase and sale of a large diamond to the Regent of France. The Swallowfield estate remained in the Pitt family until 1737 when it was sold to John Dodd. In 1783, Dodd's descendents sold it to Sylvanus Bevan, whose descendents sold it in turn in 1788 to Timothy Hare Earle, Esq. By Mitford's time, the estate had passed to Earle's son, Timothy Hare Altabon Earle. As a result of financial losses the latter had suffered in the West Indies on account of the abolition of British participation in the slave trade, he sold Swallowfield in 1820 to Sir Henry Russell. Sir Henry had recently returned to England, having spent 1798 to 1814 in India. By 1825, Sir Henry began making renovations to the property, together with son, Henry, who himself inherited Swallowfield in 1836. Mitford developed a close friendship with Lady Marie Clotilde Russell, his wife.
Swallowfield and Its Owners by Lady Constance Russell
Swallowfield Park, Berkshire by Margot Finn
A seventeenth-century public house and coaching inn next to which the Mitford family lived in Three Mile Cross. It is featured in Our Village as the Rose Inn.

Department in western France, traditionally believed to be the birthplace of Elinor of Acquitaine. During the French Revolution, the Vendee mounted a fierce resistance to the revolutionary government and later refused to recognize Napoleon's legitimacy after his escape from Elba.

The city, consisting of 118 islands in the Venetian lagoon and located in the northeastern region of Italy, has a long history stretching back into antiquity. From 697, Venice was a Republic, a city state with its own autonomous elected government of aristocrats and oligarchs, ruled by a Doge. At its height, the Republic of Venice included the Veneto region of what is now Italy, the Fruili-Venezia Giulia region that encompasses parts of present-day Austria and Slovenia, and the Istria Peninsula. The end of the Venetian Republic came in 1797 when Napoleon invaded, and ceded the territory to Austria, forcing the Doge to abdicate. In 1866, following the defeat of the Austrians, Venice was handed over to a unified Italy.
A steep, corkscrew-like hill described in A Great Farmhouse on which the farmer's greyhound, Helen proudly kills an old hare.
Location of Mr. and Mrs. Newell's farm in St. Giles parish, Berkshire, likely the model for the great farmhouse at M. in A Great Farmhouse.
A landlocked county that borders Berkshire, Gloucesteshire, Oxfordshire, Hampshire, Somerset, Hampshire, and Dorset. It encompasses Old Sarum, Salisbury, Salisbury Plain, and the Stonehenge site.

Estate purchased by the Bernard Brocas shortly before his death in 1777, and extensively renovated by his wife, Harriet. In the Our Village story, Bramley Maying, Mitford mentions W. Park, which may refer to Wokefield.
Place of employment of Joseph Hearne from A Country Cricket Match. The mills are located in an adjacent parish.
In Greek mytholody, Arcadia was the home to the god Pan, and in classical literature, indicated an unspoilt wilderness of innocence and pleasure.
A fictionalized place mentioned in The Visit, located in F. Hill, near the home of the narrator's friend from F. Hill whom she visits in that sketch. Original site as yet unidentified.
The city of B. is Mitford's screened reference to Reading in Our Village.
The initial given by Mitford for the city of Reading in Our Village. She indicates this in a letter to Sir William Elford of June 23, 1824.
Site of the Maying that the narrator of Our Village attends in Bramley Maying.

The manufacturing town that, in the Our Village sketch, Cousin Mary, the title character moves to for some months before taking a position as a governess. It is described as smokey. Location unidentified.
The loosely-screened name that Mitford gives to Farley Hill in Our Village. It is described elaborately as a new development in The Visit.
The house belonging to William Falkner and Miss Falkner. Mentioned in the Our Village sketch Ellen.
The common named in A Country Cricket Match used by the opposing teams for their cricket match. It is located within Shinfield parish.
Mentioned in the Our Village sketch Ellen. It is the home of Miss Falkner and Colonel Falkner.
A desolate common, set aside after enclosure, where Tom Cordery enjoys bringing the narrator and his unwary gentleman clients in Tom Cordery. The area may be based on Mortimer Common's Burnt Common.

The chief setting of Tom Cordery. Mitford may be indicating the village of Mortimer Common, or more specifically the common lands around it that are said to be partially enclosed at the time the story takes place.
Town mentioned in A Country Cricket Match said to be located twelve miles from Shinfield parish. It is the residence of Mary Allen. Location as yet unidentified.
Small village that the narrator tours in the story, Our Village story, Bramley Maying. Mitford is probably referring to Mortimer village.
A small town in Dorsetshire where Charlotte Page, Ellen Page, and their father reside in the Our Village sketch Ellen.
The unnamed rectory that Mr. Sidney waits most of his adult life to occupy in An Old Bachelor.
The unnamed College where Mr. Sidneyis a fellow while awaiting a vacancy at the unnamed rectory in An Old Bachelor.
Property belonging to Rector Page that is located in Ireland. Mentioned in the Our Village sketch Ellen.
The house belonging to Rector Page in the town of N., featured in the Our Village sketch Ellen.
An elevated ridge where the Our Village narrator and her friends climb in donkey carts and by foot in Cousin Mary. It may be the Finchamstead Ridges.
The Rose Inn is mentioned many times as the local inn in Our Village. It is based on the real-life Swan Inn, next to which the Mitfords lived in Three Mile Cross.
City or town on the stagecoach route from B.in Our Village. It is not clear whether this is the same location as the city of S. mentioned in Bramley Maying and Lucy.
Parish mentioned in A Country Cricket Match as the home of a rival cricket team. It is located to the southeast of the village parish. Location as yet unidentified.
The town mentioned as the usual residence of the title character of the sketch, The Talking Lady.
A crumbling old farmhouse that the narrator mourns in the sketch, Violeting.
Mentioned in the Our Village story, Bramley Maying, and probably refers to Wokefield Park.
Name of a beautiful, unenclosed common in Three Mile Cross that is referred to in several Our Village sketches.
The parish workhouse mentioned in several Our Village sketches.

item.name: Fly
item.note: In the Our Village story, The First Primrose, Fly is the dog owned by farmer Barnard.

item.name: Hector
item.note: An exquisite greyhound belonging to the farmer in A Great Farmhouse.

item.name: Helen
item.note: A greyhound featured in A Great Farmhouse.

list.item: fawn Chordata Artiodactyla Cervidae A fawn is a young deer, under one year old.-->

item.name: golden beetle
golden tortoise beetle
Charidotella
C. sexpunctata
Chrysomelidae
item.note: A species of leaf beetle that is native to the Americas.
A small bird best known for its beautiful and powerful song.

item.name: swallow
Chordata
Aves
Passeriformes
Passeri
Hirundinidae
item.note: The swallow is from a family of passerine birds found around the world on all continents except Antarctica. Highly adapted to aerial feeding, they have a distinctive appearance. The term swallow is used colloquially in Europe as a synonym for the barn swallow.
A rose is a woody perennial flowering plant. Most species are native to Asia, with some being native to North America, Europe, and northwester Africa.

item.name: auricula
primula
p. auricula
primulaceae
item.note: This flower is commonly called primula auricula, but is often known also as mountain cowslip, auricula, or bear's ear. It grows on rocks in mountain rages particularly in central Europe.

list.item: bean Vicia V. fabia Fabaceae Although there various families of beans, the broad bean is the one on file because it was the most common in England at the time. It's also known as the Windsor bean or English bean. That said, it was cultivated in the Middle East long before it reached Europe, and there's even a Greek demigod of fava beans, called Kyamites. -->

broom Cytisus C. scoparius Fabaceae Also known as Scotch broom. Represents humility and neatness in floriography. In the Fourth Branch of the Mabinogi, the tale of Math son of Mathonwy, Blodeuwedd is the name of a woman made from the flowers of broom, meadowsweet and the oak by Math fab Mathonwy and Gwydion to be the wife of Lleu Llaw Gyffes. This is a part of Welsh mythology. Sweep the house with blossed broom in May/sweep the head of the household away is a traditional rhyme from Sussex. It was common to include a decorated bundle of broom at weddings. Ashes of broom were used to treat dropsy, and said to tame wild dogs and horses with its smell. -->
crocus crocus--> iridaceae In Victorian floriography, the crocus represents youthful gladness and cheerfulness.-->

currants ribes
Grossulariaceae, or a separate genus of Grossularia Mitford calls this plant a currant-bush, which is actually another name for the conkerberry or bush plum, but these grow best in tropical regions and are likely not what she means. -->

item.note: A rose hybrid that is renowned for its fine fragrance.

list.item:
elm
Ulmus
Ulmaceae The elm is highly prominent in literature, with its first presence in the Iliad. It is also in the Aeneid, as the Stygian Elm. Virgil refers to a Roman superstition that elms were trees of ill-omen because their fruit seemed to have no value. Two elm-motifs have risen from classical literature: the 'Paradisal elm' motif, representing pastoral idylls, and the 'Elm and Death' motif. Many references to elm from the Renaissance onwards fit one of these two categories. The elm also holds political significance. The cutting of the elm was a diplomatic altercation between the Kings of France and England in 1188. In England, after the Glorious Revolution of 1688, the 'Dutch Elm' hybrid was planted and become popular with enthusiasts o the new political order. Furthermore, the 'Liberty Tree' was an American white elm in Boston. In 1775, the British felled it, and the Americans planted 'Liberty Elms' and sewed elm symbols on to their reolutionary flags.-->

item.name: geranium
geranium
perennial herb
geraniaceae
item.note: The geranium genus and the perrenial herb species. It is also called cranesbill because the genus word is greek for crane. Native mostly to subtropical Africa. It grows most commonly in the Mediterranean.

list.item: Gooseberry Ribes R. uva-cripsa Grossulariaceae In floriography, signifies anticipation.-->
gorse Ulex Ulex europaeus Fabaceae In floriography, symbolizes endearing affection. -->
grape Vitis Vitaceae A grape is a fruit, botanically a berry, of the deciduous woody vines of the flowering plant genus Vitis.-->

heath, or heather Erica
Ericaceae There are many varieties of heath, but this one is synonymous with the English common names "heath" and "heather". Heather, in floriography, can mean three different things. In general, it means good luck. White heather is protection, and that wishes will come true, while lavender heather represents admiration and solitude. The latter meaning fits. -->

alcea
malvaceae
malvaceae
item.note: This flower is commonly called alcea, but is often known as hollyhock. It is native to Asia and Europe.
A genus of shrubs in vines in the olive family that are cultivated for the fragrance of their flowers.

item.name: tiger lily
item.note: A species of lily native to Asia and eastern Russia, but that can also be cultivated in Europe and North America, the tiger lily grows from bulbs, and possesses orange and black petals that reach backward.
A genus of trees commonly referred to as lime trees in England, although they are not related to the lime fruit.
A genus of flowering plants found in Europe and North Africa.

list.item:
nose-gay
Also called tussie-mussie or a posey, the nose-gay is composed of a mixture of flowers and herbs, edged with paper frill or greens. They are associated with the floral language of love, and were popular in Victorian England. Different arrangements signified different relationship statuses.-->

potato Solanum S. tuberosum Solanaceae Potatoes are relatively new to Europe at this time. They are native to the Andes and were introduced only in the second half of the 16th century by the Spanish..-->
primrose Primula P. vulgaris Primulaceae The Earl of Rosebury has primroses in his coat of arms. It also projects the meaning I can't live without you in floriography -->

ranunculu
ranunculaceae
Ranunculaceae
item.note: This flower is commonly a genus of about 600 plants includings buttercups, spearworts, and water crowfoots.

item.name: rose-tree
rosa
rosaceae
item.note: There are over a hundred species of roses, but not all of them are suitable to be made into what is known as a rose-tree.
A perennial plant that is frequently used in perfumes.

item.name: tulip
tulipa
perennial
liliaceae
item.note: This flower is from the tulipa genus and the perrenial species. It grows most commonly in the Mediterranean, but grows in gardens and in potted plants.

list.item: willow Salix Salix alba Salicaceae The leaves and bark of the willow tree has been mentioned as a remedy for aches and fever in ancient texts from Assyria, Sumer and Egypt. Hippocrates mentioned this plant for its medicinial properties, and the Native Americans also used willow for a staple in medical treatments. In 1763, Reverend Edward Stone in England notified the Royal Society of his findings that the willow had medicinal properties. In 1828, Henri Leroux, a French pharmacist, and Raffaele Piria, an Italiam chemist, isolated the bark extract, called salicin, into a crystalline form and separated into a pure state.-->

event.label: Act for the Abolition of the Slave Trade
event.note: The Parliamentary Act passed in 1807 that abolished English participation in the slave trade.

event.label: Slavery Abolition Act

An Act for the Abolition of Slavery throughout the British Colonies; for promoting the Industry of the manumitted Slaves; and for compensating the Persons hitherto entitled to the Services of such Slaves
Peninsular War
the War of Spanish Independence
event.note: Part of the Napoleonic Wars, the Peninsular War was fought between the French against an alliance of Spanish, Portuguese, and British armies. Napoleon occupied Portugal and parts of Spain, forcing the abdication of King Charles IV and his son, King Ferdinand VI. They were replaced with his own brother, Joseph Bonaparte. The war was fought through guerilla tactics and direct military engagements, and enhanced the career of the Duke of Wellington, who fought across the Pyrenees to push back Bonaparte's forces. Upon the conclusion of the war, King Ferdinand reascended the throne.

item.note: White marble tomb sculpted by Thomas Banks, dedicated to Bernard Brocas. The tomb's effigy represents a dying Brocas in the arms of his wife. It was installed in the church of St. James in Bramley around 1800. Mitford saw the monument on May 23, 1822, piece is described in the Our Village story, Bramley Maying.

figure.note: Portrait of a young woman wearing a black straw hat.

bibl.title: The Four Times of the Day
bibl.author: William Hogarth

figure.note: A four-part series of paintings by Hogarth set in different parts of London, at distinct times of the day, and titled accordingly: Morning, Noon, Evening, and Night. Each work features figures from various classes of people going about their business. The series was engraved and published in 1738.

bibl.title: The Maid of the Mill
The First Scene of the Maid of the Mill
A Catalogue Raisonne of the Engraved Works of William Woollett
bibl.author: William Woollett

figure.note: Engraving modeled after stage scene painting by John Inigo Richards. It depicts a young man gesturing while walking across a mill yard surrounded by three buildings, being watched on the right by a young woman from a second-floor house window, and two other women on the left who are mending a net outside a barn. Two older men work in the mill in the background.

bibl.title: The Ballad of Chevy Chase
bibl.author: anonymous
bibl.note: An old English ballad that tells the story of the dispute between Percy, the Duke of Northumberland and the Scottish Earl Douglas over hunting. It was much admired in Mitford's time, having been published in a number of ballad collections, including Reliques of Ancient English Poetry. Its tune had also been adapted with other lyrics.

bibl.title: The Last Letters of Jacopo Ortis
bibl.author: Ugo Foscolo
bibl.note: Epistolary novel in the spirit of Goethe's Werther but with political overtones that link the hero, Ortis, to the Venetian struggle for indepependence and liberty. The protagonist is in love with a woman, Teresa, who is betrothed to another, while also enduring dashed political hopes with fall of Venice into the hands of Austria. He communicates his feelings to a friend in letters while on his travels. Mitford records in her journal reading this book on June 15, 1820.

bibl.title: Le Sylph
Le Sylph

title.foreign: ou le mari comme il y en a peu

bibl.author: Martin de Choisy
bibl.note: A comic French play in verse.

bibl.title: The Chronicle
The Chronicle
A Ballad
bibl.author: Abraham Cowley
bibl.note: A comic poem in which the author lists the names of many supposed mistresses and how the relationships ended.

bibl.title: Animal Biography, or Authentic Anecdotes of the Lives, Manners, and Economy of the Animal Creation
bibl.author: William Bingley
bibl.note: A popular work of natural history that eventually expanded into four volumes and went into six editions. Covering animals and insects from all over the world, the book makes use of the work of predecessors, such as Linnaeus and Gilbert White to present minute descriptions of animal life.

bibl.title: The Book of Common Prayer and Administration of the Sacraments and other Rites and Ceremonies of the Church, according to the use of the Church of England, Together with the Psalter or Psalms of David, pointed as they are to be Sung or said in churches
bibl.author: Thomas Cranmer
bibl.note: The established liturgy of the Church of England. The book was first composed during the English Reformation, and aimed to make the rituals of the church more accessible to the worshippers by describing them in English rather than Latin. It encompasses forms of worship, service, prayers, and sacraments. Its use was authorized by Parliament in 1549, and it has undergone important revisions over the centuries. Many phrases from the book have gone into common discourse.

bibl.title: English Local Government: The Story of the King's Highway
bibl.author: Sidney Webb
Beatrice Webb

bibl.title: Joe Miller's Jests
or the Wits Vade-Mecum
bibl.author: John Mottley
bibl.note: A book of jokes that was published one year after the death of its titular author, Joe Miller. First published as a pamphlet, the edition was so successful that it went into three editions. Later joke books bearing his name followed, under slightly different titles. Joe Miller books remained well known until the nineteenth century.

bibl.title: The History of the Adventures of Joseph Andrews and of his friend Mr. Abraham Adams
bibl.author: Henry Fielding
bibl.note: This picaresque novel, a loose satirical response to Pamela, tells of her brother's adventures on his way to London with his companion Parson Adams. Joseph is dismissed from service for rejecting the advances of Lady Booby, the wife of his deceased employer, and meets Adams who is on the way to sell his sermons in London.

bibl.title: A Journal of the Plague Year
History of the Plague in London
bibl.author: Daniel Defoe
H.F.
bibl.note: Often described as a historical novel, Defoe's work is presented as the eyewitness account of a London saddler to the events of the bubonic plague outbreak in London in the year 1665. Defoe was about five years old when the plague broke out, so it is unlikely that the narrative of events and places are from his own perspective or are meant to be taken as a genuine eyewitness account, despite the verisimilitude of the text. Defoe may have consulted the journals of his uncle, Henry Foe, the H.F. of the pseudonym, for some of his material.

bibl.title: A Legend of Montrose
Tales of My Landlord
bibl.note: Novel published in the Third Series of the Tales of My Landlord, along with The Bride of Lammermoor. It tells the story of the conflict between the royalist Earl of Montrose and the Scottish Covenanters during the English Civil War, focusing as well on the personal struggles between Allan M'Aulay and his romantic rival, the earl of Menteith for the affection of Annot Lyle.

bibl.title: Life of Samuel Johnson, L.L.D.
bibl.author: James Boswell
bibl.note: Influential and controversial biography of Samuel Johnson that came to set a standard for life-writing in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

bibl.title: The Lover's Melancholy
bibl.author: John Ford
bibl.note: This play by John Ford was based on Robert Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy. It was first performed in 1628 at the Blackfriar's and the Globe Theaters. By Mitford's time, the play had garnered the praise of Charles Lamb, who anthologized portions in his Specimens of English Dramatic Poets.

bibl.title: Love's Labour's Lost
A Pleasant and Conceited Comedie Called Loves Labours Lost [sic]
bibl.author: William Shakespeare
bibl.note: In this early comedy, Ferdinand, the King of Navarre, and his three courtiers renounce love, but end up enamored with the Princess of France and her attendants. The play was published in the First Folio.

bibl.author: William Shakespeare
bibl.note: Shakespeare's comedy of disguises and love tests features Ferdinand, the King of Navarre and three friends, Berowne, Longaville, and Dumaine, who renounce love in favor of study, only to be thrown into passion by an embassy visit from the Princess of France and her three friends. The men decide to give up their oath to renounce love, and to woo the women but in disguise as Russians. The women, as a jest, swap their own identities in order to hear the suits and mock the men, but in the end, the Princess must return to France when her father dies. She gives King Ferdinand and his friends a command to spend the year performing certain tasks in order to gain the consent of the women to marriage.

bibl.title: The Maid of La Vendee, being a second edition of Clara de Montfier
Clara de Monfier; a moral tale
bibl.author: Elizabeth Anne LeNoir
bibl.note: The Maid of La Vendee is the re-titled second edition of Elizabeth LeNoir's 1808 novel, Clara de Montfier. Both editions appear to have been published by members of LeNoir's family, who owned and operated the Reading Mercury.
Biography of Elizabeth LeNoir by Laura Ridley. Corvey 'Adopt an Author'

bibl.title: A Naturalist's Calandar: with Observations in Various Branches of Natural History
bibl.author: Gilbert White
bibl.note: This book, published posthumously, gives precise accounts of the actions of animals, bird sounds, and weather phenomena, all of which were noted by hand in tabular form by the author, and rendered in the same format in the book. It was later often republished with The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne.

bibl.title: The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne
bibl.author: Gilbert White
bibl.note: This influential book of nature writing is ostensibly formed from 110 letters addressed by the author to Thomas Pennant, a zoologist, and Daines Barrington, a fellow of the Royal Society. In each letter, some of which were composed for the book itself, White describes his observations of local natural surroundings, flora, fauna, and geologic formation in minute detail. These observations were carefully prepared from notes White took over time, and were meant to be a scientific record of the natural phenomena under discussion, coupled with an assessment of the social conditions of the area. The book was immensely successful, and is considered an early example of ecological exploration. It was a favorite book of Mitford's, and she invokes it as a formal model for Our Village in the introductory sketch, and refers to it frequently.

bibl.title: Ode: Intimations of Immortality from Recollections of Early Childhood
bibl.author: William Wordsworth
bibl.note: Originally published in Poems, in Two Volumes, Wordsworth's eleven-stanza irregular Pindaric ode explores questions of the soul, and the wisdom of childhood.

bibl.title: On the Pleasure Arising from Vicissitude
Ode on the Pleasure Arising from Vicissitude
The Poems of Mr. Gray
bibl.author: Thomas Gray
bibl.note: An unfinished ode published posthumously.

bibl.title: Our Miss Austen: Jane Austen and Mary Russell Mitford--A New Appraisal
Persuasions: The Jane Austen Journal
bibl.author: Azar Hussain

bibl.title: The Palace of Truth: a moral tale
bibl.author: Madame de Genlis
bibl.note: A moral tale.

bibl.title: Pamela; or, Virtue Rewarded
bibl.author: Samuel Richardson
bibl.note: This acclaimed, influential, but controversial epistolary novel tells the story of fifteen-year old Pamela Andrews, the daughter of laboring-class parents, as she fends off the sexual advances of her rakish employer, Mr. B. When he eventually proposes to her, she doubts his sincerity, but later realizes that she loves him, and accepts his proposal. The novel interrogates issues of class and gender as they affect feeling.

bibl.title: The Parish Register
Poems
bibl.author: George Crabbe
bibl.note: A pastoral poem by George Crabbe, recounting stories of the parish poor from the point of view of the clergyman. It is divided into three parts: Baptisms, Marriages, and Burials. The poem was published as part of a collection entitled Poems.

bibl.title: Pilgrim's Progress from This World, to that Which is to Come
bibl.author: John Bunyan
bibl.note: Allegorical novel that tells the story of a protagonist named Christian on a journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City. On his way, he meets various characters like Evangelist, Pliable, Mr. Legality and his son, Civility, as he roams through the Shadow of Death, the Slough of Despond, the Hill of Difficulty, and Wicket Gate. The first part of the book was written while Bunyan was in imprisoned in the county jail. He published the second part, which deals with Christian's wife and sons, several years later.

bibl.title: The Polite Letter Writer
bibl.note: A book published in the 1800s that detailed rules of composition and provided examples of different types of letters. More research needed.

bibl.title: The Porter and the Three Ladies
bibl.note: A story from the first volume of Arabian Nights.

bibl.title: The Seasons
bibl.author: James Thomson
bibl.note: A four-part, blank-verse pastoral poem sequence, beginning with Winter and ending with Autumn. It was published as four separate poems beginning in 1726, until it was finally collected as The Seasons in 1730. The work was influential on writers from the mid-eighteenth century to the nineteenth century for its contemplative feeling mixed with descriptions of scenery.

bibl.title: The Silent Woman
Epicene
bibl.author: Ben Jonson
bibl.note: Comic play by Ben Jonson that premiered at the Whitefriars Theater in either December 1609 or January 1610, and was the first play performed at the Restoration after the reopening of the theaters in 1660. The play features a noise-despising man named Morose who tries to disherit his nephew, Dauphine, by marrying. The nephew subsequently tricks Morose into marrying a mysteriously quiet woman, who turns out to be not only talkative, but also a boy.

bibl.author: William Shakespeare
bibl.note: Part of a song sequence performed as part of the play-within-the-play at the end of Love's Labour's Lost. This section is sung by Ver, the Spring, represented by the cuckoo.

bibl.title: Specimens of English Dramatic Poets, who lived about the time of Shakespeare
bibl.author: Charles Lamb
bibl.note: Lamb's anthology of excerpts from Elizabethan dramatists and poets helped popularize the era's authors for the early nineteenth century. The book included works by John Ford, Thomas Kyd, Thomas Decker, John Fletcher, Christopher Marlowe, and Ben Jonson, among others, with notes written by Lamb.

bibl.title:
Stories or Tales of Times Past Tales of Mother Goose
Histoire ou contes du temps passe
les contes de ma mere l'oye
bibl.author: Charles Perrault
bibl.note: Influential book of fairy tales that helped popularize such stories as Cinderella; or the Little Glass Slipper, Little Red Riding Hood, The Sleeping Beauty in the Wood, The Master Cat; or Puss in Bootsand Blue Beard. Perrault likely based his tales on those found in earlier European collections and those of some of his contemporaries, and incorporated the style and values of French aristocratic society, ending each tale with a moral. The first English translation of the book was produced in 1729, leading to the stories' widespread popularity in various forms and versions, including as lavishly illustrated children's books well into the nineteenth century.

bibl.title: The Picture; or The Lover's Resolution
Morning Post
bibl.author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
bibl.title: Sybilline Leaves
bibl.note: Meditative poem first published in the Morning Post, and later published in the Love Poems section of Sybilline Leaves. It features several lines that appear in Coleridge's preface to Kubla Khan.

bibl.title: The Task: a Poem, in Six Books
bibl.author: William Cowper
bibl.note: An immensely influential long blank-verse poem that meditates on the blessings of nature and the retired life. The poem comments on war, slavery, despotism, and other issues of moment. Like other romantic-era writers, Mitford greatly admired the work.

bibl.title: The Minor
bibl.note: A comic play that ridiculed the Methodist preacher, George Whitefield. It was performed at The Haymarket in 1760, and subsequently moved to Drury Lane later that year.

bibl.author: George Farquhar
bibl.note: Comic play that was widely performed throughout the eighteenth century. It features the character of a recruiting sergeant named Kite, who attempts to trick a woman into marrying the Captain for whom he works.

bibl.title: Verses Making Part of an Epitaph on the Same Lady
A Collection of Poems in Six Volumes. By Several Hands.
bibl.author: George Lyttelton
bibl.note: A twelve-line elegy to George Lyttelton's first wife, which also became the inscription on her tombstone. It was much-quoted (and misquoted) into the nineteenth century, often with the gender changed to male and outside the context of elegy.

bibl.title: Yew Trees
Poems in Two Volumes
bibl.author: William Wordsworth
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Reese, Orme and Brown
bibl.note: Poem written around 1804 and published in the Poems of the Imagination section of the first volume of Poems in Two Volumes. It describes ancient trees, and imagines their longstanding relationship to history. Mitford admired the poem, and mentioned it to Sir William Elford in a letter from September 26, 1819.
